channel.title: Community Moderation (suggestion)
channel.description:
[url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,408682.msg3018274.html#msg3018274]Allow users to select if they think a post breaks the rules, and if a certain number of different people feel this way, the post will be hidden by default, with an option for others to see it.[/url]
That is listed as a todo, so I would like to do it.
How is the question, so I am asking for feedback before I do it this way that people might not like. Also, if you think this is a bad idea, say so, it's all up for discussion.
My idea is to use the existing 'report to moderator' functionality already built into the forum, and if X (we will have to pick a good value for X) number of people report a particular post and/or topic, I can either:
a) hide it by default, marking it as potential spam, allowing individual users to click 'show me this post' as they wish. b) change it to an un-approved post/topic, requiring a staff member to look at it and either approve or delete it.
Either way, the report would still remain and a staff member would punish the offender appropriately. This would simply allow users to immediately take care of blatant spam even if a staff member was not on.
I am also thinking this shouldn't be available to brand new members, maybe only 'Members' (50 post count) and up?
So, start the discussion.

item.title: Community Moderation (suggestion)
item.dc:creator: @eXemplar eXemplar
item.description:
@eXemplar wrote:

Just my 2c on this whole idea of community moderation, a lot of you probably already know what I mean if you use any form of social media/news aggregation sites (ie, reddit).

The #1 problem with community moderation is it turns everything into a popularity contest. For example,
User1: runescape is shit because x/y/z
User2…n: omg ur shit, - rating dikhed
Net result: Thread burried, user receives bad rep purely for saying something which isn’t necessarily wrong but against the popular belief. In this example, although maybe on this topic would be unlikely to happen, you could lose a really interesting conversation and back/forwards between both sides. Then you end up getting popular users who attract more attention for no real reason other than they appear popular (read: have higher votes) and a backlash to lower voted users, which only attracts more negativity. Also you end up with down rating cliques forming who can bury things just because they hold sway over a few users.

It’s a community anti-magnet, where + attracts + and - attracts -

Also, where do you draw the line between comment and post? It’s far too open to individual interpretation, and I’m pretty sure if you looked up reply in a dictionary a few would probably list see: comment.

Further edit:
Personally, I think a better approach to this would be to move forward from using flat, linear and, let’s face it, ancient bbs style forums and move towards proper branching/threaded forums (again, reddit). As far as guaging users and input, I don’t know, maybe some form of signal to noise ratio? A representation of post count vs rep/rating per post or overall vs length of time browing forums vs how long user has been registered for. Anyways, that’s more idle thought than anything.

item.title: Community Moderation (suggestion)
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:40, topic:326668”][quote author=BAsh link=topic=423079.msg3107808#msg3107808 date=1264296305]

making comments on a forum post…? wow guyths

I think its a good idea. It allows people to have a dig at them while keeping the thread on track. In this community people are going to abuse each other hidden posts or not.
[/quote]

I see where frank_ is coming from, at first commenting on a post sounds like a stupid idea. But I really think, in this community, it would stop thread de-railing and keep only relevant comments in the thread.

People can quote for commenting.

I think that is the problem, when someone posts something stupid. Now whether you have value to add to the conversation, or whether you just want to call them on being an idiot, you have to make a post, then they fight back, derailing the thread. If this system was implemented, and someone, for example, posted an idiotic comment possibly with wrong information in it, a person simply wanting to flame them would use the rating/comment system, and a person wanting to provide actual content to the thread, such as correct info, would make a post.[/quote]

Actually, now that I think about it that way, it is a very good idea.
Limiting actual posts to only valuable and relevant information to the thread, and keeping spam in offside comments.
